A law of composition on a set $M$ is said to be associative if $(ab)c = a(bc)$ for all elements $a, b, c \in M$.

The dihedral group $D_{n}$, for $n \geq 3$, is the group of symmetries (rotations and reflections) of a regular (convex) $n$-gon. It is generated by the permutations $\sigma = (1, \ldots, n)$ and $\tau = \left(\begin{array}{ccccc}1 & 2 & 3 & \ldots & n \\ 1 & n & n-1 & \ldots & 2\end{array}\right)$.
Does the concept of a/an Associative Law need to be defined for a definition of a/an Dihedral Group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a Dihedral Group involves the group of symmetries of a regular polygon, which includes operations such as rotations and reflections. These operations can be represented by permutations, and the group is defined by specific generators. A group, by definition in mathematics, is a set equipped with a binary operation that satisfies four fundamental properties: closure, associativity, identity, and inverses.

The Associative Law, as defined, states that a law of composition on a set is associative if it satisfies the condition 
$(ab)c = a(bc)$ for all elements $a, b, c$ in the set. This law is crucial for the structure of any mathematical group because it ensures that the way in which elements are grouped during the operation does not affect the outcome.

Therefore, for the definition of a Dihedral Group to make sense and to be complete, it inherently relies on the concept of the Associative Law. The operations within the group must satisfy this law to fulfill the definition of a group. Without the Associative Law, the set of symmetries described by the Dihedral Group would not necessarily form a group in the mathematical sense.
